Award.AwardTitle: Studies of clathrin-mediated endocytosis in a millisecond time resolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chemical synapses within the brain are specialized cellular junctions that are vastly
intergraded to allow for rapid, highly-specific communication between neurons. Fusion of
neurotransmitter-containing vesicles with the plasma membrane, subsequent release and
activation of postsynaptic receptors executes a phase called exocytosis. To prevent the limited
number of synaptic vesicles from rapid depletion, a secondary system of webbed pathways
replenishes the vesicle pool through several modes known as endocytosis. Although the exocytic
pathway, with its signaling cascade and key proteins are confidently defined, the true nature of
vesicle re-formation is less clear. The proposed study will investigate the molecular mechanisms
of endocytosis using biophysical and electrochemical methods with milli-second time resolution.
We expect that this work will illustrate the functions of several important endocytic proteins in
endocytosis.

The results from this work will likely lead to important insights into synaptic vesicle
recycling, which is critical for higher functions of our brain, such as learning and memory. These
results will shed new light on a signaling cascade that defines the hallmark of inter-cellular
communication and aid in identifying aspects of cellular health, thus revealing a deeper
understanding of what functional mechanism(s) are involved in the dominant and most
fundamental endocytic portal. The investigators will also be dedicated to the training of
undergraduate and graduate students in scientific research, through discussion in classes and
research in laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal is to understand the regulation of clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME) using cell-attached capacitance techniques in millisecond time resolution. This CME is essential for regeneration of synaptic vesicles, which is a fundamental component for mediating communications between neurons. Elucidating the mechanisms for CME is thus essential for our understanding of brain functions.

We have published 4 papers in academic journals and 2 manuscripts are in preparation. During the funding period, we have trained 4 graduate students and 5 undergraduate students. And graudate student also went to scientific meeting to present their work, which is critical to train them as a scientist.The undergraduate students had hands-on experience on electrophysiology, cell culture, meolular bilogy and so on, which is important for them to develop interests in sceince. We also had 2 high school students working in the lab during their summer time, which helped them to develop interests in biology. And one of the student was highly interested in biology and he is in medical school now, actually.

The findings from thsi proposal have been present to stduents in "Bilogy of the Brain", an undergraduate class. This class has been taught by the PI with more than 120 students in Fall annually. Many students got interested in our work and typically more than half of the students visited the lab and learned more about our work than what are covered in the classroom.

UIC had Brain Bee program, which brought hundreds of high school students to visit Neuroscience labs they are interested. Our lab has been heavily involved in this program and most of the students visited our lab and learned our work with both graduate students and the PI.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2017
Modified by: Liang-Wei Gong
